title: Zion's Glorious Foundation
shortSummary: Psalm 87 celebrates the unique and exalted status of Zion, God's chosen city, as the spiritual foundation for His people. It highlights the inclusion of diverse nations into God's covenant community, emphasizing God's sovereign establishment and blessing upon Zion.
timeline: c. 10th century BC - United Monarchy period, attributed to the sons of Korah

keyCharacters.name: Sons of Korah
keyCharacters.description: A group of Levitical singers and temple musicians traditionally credited with composing this Psalm, emphasizing worship and praise.

keyCharacters.name: Rahab
keyCharacters.description: A poetic name often symbolizing Egypt or a powerful nation, mentioned here as a representative of foreign peoples known to God.

keyCharacters.name: Babylon
keyCharacters.description: A prominent ancient city representing foreign nations, included to show the broad reach of God's covenant blessings.

keyCharacters.name: Philistia, Tyre, Ethiopia
keyCharacters.description: Nations mentioned to illustrate the inclusion of Gentiles into the spiritual family of Zion.

definitions.definition: A biblical poetic term often used to symbolize Egypt or a powerful foreign nation, representing the enemies or outsiders in the Old Testament.
A term found frequently in the Psalms, likely indicating a pause for contemplation or musical interlude.
The hill in Jerusalem on which the city of David was built, symbolizing God's chosen dwelling place and the spiritual center of His people.
Refers to the sacred hills around Jerusalem where God's temple was established, signifying divine presence and authority.

outline.heading: The Foundation of Zion
outline.description: The Psalm opens by declaring Zion's foundation in the holy mountains and God's special love for its gates above all dwellings of Jacob, emphasizing its divine selection and protection.

outline.heading: Glorious Reputation of the City of God
outline.description: The Psalmist proclaims the glorious things spoken of Zion, inviting reflection on its honored status among nations.

outline.heading: Inclusion of Foreign Nations
outline.description: God mentions Rahab, Babylon, Philistia, Tyre, and Ethiopia, symbolizing the incorporation of Gentile peoples into Zion’s spiritual family, highlighting God's grace beyond Israel.

outline.heading: Divine Registration of the Born in Zion
outline.description: The Psalm affirms that God Himself records those born in Zion, signifying divine acknowledgment and eternal belonging.

outline.heading: Joyful Worship in Zion
outline.description: The Psalm concludes with a vision of worshipers—both singers and instrumentalists—celebrating in Zion, portraying the city as the source of spiritual life and joy.

application: Recognize and cherish the special place God has established for His people, committing to spiritual foundations rooted in His Word.
Embrace the inclusiveness of God's kingdom, praying for and welcoming those from diverse backgrounds into the family of faith.
Trust that God personally knows and records those who belong to Him, encouraging assurance of salvation and identity in Christ.
Engage in heartfelt worship as a response to God's blessings, using music and praise to deepen fellowship with Him.

keyVerses.text: The LORD loveth the gates of Zion more than all the dwellings of Jacob.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights God's special love and preference for Zion, underscoring its spiritual importance.

keyVerses.text: I will make mention of Rahab and Babylon to them that know me: behold Philistia, and Tyre, with Ethiopia; this man was born there.
keyVerses.significance: It reveals God's inclusive plan to incorporate Gentile nations into His covenant community.

keyVerses.text: The LORD shall count, when he writeth up the people, that this man was born there. Selah.
keyVerses.significance: This verse assures believers that God personally acknowledges and records their belonging to His people.

keyVerses.text: As well the singers as the players on instruments shall be there: all my springs are in thee.
keyVerses.significance: It portrays Zion as the source of spiritual joy and worship, emphasizing the vitality found in God's presence.
